text:
Sure, but that’s attributing causality.
The hypothesis test tells you if there is evidence to reject your null hypothesis, which is a statement about the avg infection rate difference in the population.
So it will tell you that.
But that is not the thing we are actually interested in.
We are actually interested in the transmissability.
So we need to control for everything else.

text:
As a particular example of why looking at those statistics alone will mislead is if you look at the figures for Australia.

Right now there are about 120 active cases in Australia
20 of them are from overseas and are in hotel quarantine.
We can assume those probably are a random scattering of variants.
but the other 100 are an outbreak in Sydney, which can be traced to a single person who had contact with people in quarantine.

So if you look at those statistics it will say that that one variant is much more common — 100 cases vs everything else having only 20 combined.

Further, even if you look at number of cases transmitted it will say similar.
That variant has had 100 people catch it.
the others have had 0.
because they are in quarentine.

text:
The UK goverement saying this varient is more transmissable  is dangerously convenient.
and that justification doesn’t really seem true to me
Original, three tiers didn’t have things under-control — if it did we wouldn’t have needed lockdown 2.0
and the cases started rising a few days after that lockdown was relaxed.

I am not saying it is not more transmissible, but I don’t trust that justification.
(I do trust more the studies that looked at what the mutations are and why those would or would not make it more transmissable.)

text:
Definitely cannot view more infections detected as evidence of transmissibility. Infections are still very low proportion of population, which means very susceptible to founder effects and other random outcomes

I don't know what this means in terms of Bayes or t tests, but I know it is very easy to fool yourself into thinking you see a phenotype when what you're really seeing is random.

As an example, if you model equal proportions of replicators with equal fitness, after usually a few dozens of generations, you only see one type of replicator left. Because at random, one will start to dominate
